description: Possibly a metaphorical use of a name for a board connecting a duck hutch to a yard.

entries.meaning: One of a long series of boards laid from side to side as a path across wet or muddy ground; normally used in plural.
examples: In an attempt to alleviate the problem, wooden planking, known as duckboards, was placed at the bottom of trenches and across other areas of muddy or waterlogged ground.

entries.meaning: Wooden, low walkway or short part of a path with one or more planks, logs, or boards laid after each other lengthwise, often two planks wide; also called bog board, bog bridge, or puncheon.

A panel of wooden slats typically lain on a concrete floor in a workshop. Compliance of slats arranged in two crossed layers reduces fatigue for a person operating a machine tool or working at a bench.
